newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay sugar weak on low demand, trade at low ebb.
newsitem.headline: Bombay sugar weak on low demand, trade at low ebb.

text.p: Sugar prices remained weak on the local market on Monday due to low end-of-month demand for physicals and trading was subdued due to limited supply, dealers said.
Ready delivery sugar S-30 fell five rupees to 1,470/1,495 a quintal and M-30 also fell five rupees to 1,495/1,525.
Inflow of sugar from mills to the market remained low because local millers have already sold their allotted quantity of sugar out of the free sale quota for July.
Mill delivery sugar eased to 1,415/1,420 rupees per quintal against 1,420/1,430 for S-30 variety, while M-30 dropped 5-10 rupees to 1,435/1,440.
The free sale quota for July is 750,000 tonnes and the Indian government has already announced a quota of 750,000 tonnes for August.

"Local sugar prices will move in a narrow range until month-end, but will pick up next month on the back of festival buying," said Shantilal Dedhiya, Secretary to the Bombay Sugar Merchant Association.
